BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Despite a structured MEL framework , there is lack of  data management on outcomes in partner level. It results in fragmented data reporting and inconsistency in outcome assessments. (High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Some improvements have been made through alignment with specific program indicators, but broader integration remains weak.
BAT.Support Required: A cross-cutting MEL framework that aligns all thematic programs under a unified strategy.
BAT.Support Possible: MEL consultants can provide advisory services to integrate strategic priorities into MEL design.
BAT.Key Requirements: Development of a standardized MEL framework ensuring coherence across thematic areas. (Swasti-BAT MEL Analysis, 2025)
BAT.Capacity Building: Training sessions on aligning MEL processes across Safe Migration, Prevention, and Child Protection.
BAT.Templates: MEL framework templates with defined reporting structures.
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs for MEL integration across thematic programs.
BAT.Users/Target Audience: MEL team, Project Managers, Partner Organizations, Donors.
BAT.Expected Outcomes: Improved data consistency and strategic decision-making.

BAT.Themes & Details: Focus Areas: Organisation Level, Program Level, Project Level
BAT.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: MEL structures are embedded at all levels but require better integration.
BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Coordination between partners, state, and field levels is inconsistent, leading to duplicated efforts and inefficient reporting. (High/High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Some initiatives have streamlined reporting at the project level but require broader standardization.
BAT.Support Required: Centralized reporting templates and systems that integrate data across levels.
BAT.Support Possible: MEL partners can facilitate training on integrated data collection methodologies.
BAT.Key Requirements: Standardized reporting protocols ensuring seamless data flow from project to program to organizational levels.
BAT.Capacity Building: Training on dashboard usage, data visualization, and real-time tracking.
BAT.Templates: Dashboard input forms, visualization templates, and analytics tools.
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs for dashboard data entry, maintenance, and usage.
BAT.Users/Target Audience: MEL team, Data Analysts, Partner Organizations.
BAT.Expected Outcomes: Enhanced program monitoring, automated reporting, and real-time insights.

BAT.Themes & Details: Theory of Change: Key Components, Strength of Association, Pathways of Change
BAT.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: ToC exists but lacks full implementation across programs, particularly in Safe Migration. (Swasti-BAT MEL Analysis, 2025)
BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Weak links between intervention activities and impact measurement, leading to difficulties in tracking long-term outcomes. (Moderate/High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: ToC frameworks are partially embedded but not consistently referenced in evaluations.
BAT.Support Required: Development of a ToC-based results framework aligning with sectoral impact goals.
BAT.Support Possible: MEL trainers can guide program teams in designing ToC-driven impact measurement strategies.
BAT.Key Requirements: A robust ToC framework linked to specific programmatic interventions and external impact measurement indicators.
BAT.Capacity Building: Capacity-building on data validation, error detection, and reporting standards.
BAT.Templates: Data validation checklists, verification templates, and quality control logs.
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs for quality assurance measures, error correction, and verification workflows.
BAT.Users/Target Audience: MEL team, Field Coordinators, Partner Organizations.
BAT.Expected Outcomes: Increased data reliability, reducing discrepancies in MEL reporting.

BAT.Themes & Details: Theory of Action/Logframe: Across Levels, Across Pillars
BAT.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Logframes exist but are inconsistently used across thematic areas.
BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Lack of standard indicators results in varied data interpretation across projects. (Moderate/High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Logframes have been successfully implemented in some partner projects, but wider adoption is needed.
BAT.Support Required: Implementation of a standard logframe template with defined core indicators.
BAT.Support Possible: MEL trainers can provide workshops on the development and use of logframes.
BAT.Key Requirements: A standardized logframe system ensuring consistency in performance tracking.
BAT.Capacity Building: Training on mixed-method evaluation approaches and participatory methodologies.
BAT.Templates: Evaluation framework templates incorporating qualitative and quantitative indicators.
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs for conducting baseline, midline, and endline evaluations.
BAT.Users/Target Audience: MEL team, External Evaluators, Partner Organizations.
BAT.Expected Outcomes: More systematic and comparable evaluations across thematic areas.

BAT.Themes & Details: Input Tracking System: Service Delivery, Capacity Building, MIS
BAT.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Partner organizations report input tracking data, but a centralized system is missing.
BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Fragmentation in input tracking creates inefficiencies in monitoring service delivery and training impact. (High/High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Various input tracking systems exist but lack integration across all partners.
BAT.Support Required: Development of a centralized MIS to track services, trainings, and program inputs.
BAT.Support Possible: Technical partners can assist with MIS development and deployment.
BAT.Key Requirements: A real-time data collection and tracking system to consolidate input monitoring.
BAT.Capacity Building: Training on real-time data collection, digital reporting, and partner-level input tracking.
BAT.Templates: MIS reporting templates, service tracking logs, and training documentation formats.
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs for system integration, partner data entry, and progress reporting.
BAT.Users/Target Audience: MEL team, Partner Leads, Program Implementers.
BAT.Expected Outcomes: Increased efficiency in tracking program inputs and service delivery.

BAT.Themes & Details: Process Quality Assurance: Budget & Resources, Quality Checks, Implementation Fidelity
BAT.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: No formalized system for quality assurance exists, leading to inconsistencies.
BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Data validation protocols are weak, causing reliability concerns in reports. (High/High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Quality checks have been informally applied but lack structured guidance.
BAT.Support Required: Establishment of a quality assurance framework with defined validation methods.
BAT.Support Possible: MEL advisors can provide SOPs and training on data validation and quality control.
BAT.Key Requirements: A standardized quality assurance system ensuring accuracy and reliability in MEL data.
BAT.Capacity Building: Capacity-building on establishing minimum quality benchmarks for data reporting, service tracking, and program evaluation. (V2 MEL Slide 15)
BAT.Templates: FPAI MEL Quality Review Checklist, Quality Compliance Audit Template
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Data Validation, Quality Review, and Compliance
BAT.Users/Target Audience: Quality Assurance Teams, MEL Officers, Field Supervisors
BAT.Expected Outcomes: Systematic quality control across all MEL components, improving reliability.
BAT.Rationale and References: QA gaps compromise reporting accuracy, necessitating a structured data validation and quality assurance framework. (V2 MEL Slide 15)

BAT.Themes & Details: Outcome Monitoring System: Journals, RBMS/MIS, Dashboard, Case Studies
BAT.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Some tools are available, but outcome monitoring lacks integration.
BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: The absence of a centralized dashboard limits data visualization and timely analysis. (Moderate/High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Case studies and qualitative data collection exist but are not systematically linked to MEL outcomes.
BAT.Support Required: Creation of a digital outcome monitoring system integrating qualitative and quantitative data.
BAT.Support Possible: MEL tech partners can support dashboard development with real-time reporting features.
BAT.Key Requirements: A real-time, interactive dashboard with data integration across programs.
BAT.Capacity Building: Training on real-time visualization of data through interactive dashboards, enabling evidence-based decision-making. (Transcript 00:40:00, OH Journal Section 9.1)
BAT.Templates: Outcome Monitoring Dashboard Design, KPI Dashboard Framework
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Dashboard Setup, Data Visualization, and Real-Time Analytics
BAT.Users/Target Audience: MEL Teams, Senior Leadership, Partner Organizations
BAT.Expected Outcomes: Faster program adaptation through dynamic, real-time insights.
BAT.Rationale and References: Outcome tracking remains fragmented due to limited dashboard integration. (Transcript 00:40:00, OH Journal Section 9.1)

BAT.Themes & Details: Evaluation System: Baseline, Endline, Quantitative/Qualitative, Annual/Donor-Specific Evaluations
BAT.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Evaluations are conducted, but methodologies vary across programs.
BAT.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Inconsistent evaluation frameworks lead to gaps in comparative impact assessment. (Moderate/High)
BAT.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Experience in donor-driven evaluations exists, but a unified internal evaluation structure is lacking.
BAT.Support Required: Development of a comprehensive evaluation strategy aligning all programs.
BAT.Support Possible: MEL experts can support methodological training and evaluation framework design.
BAT.Key Requirements: Standardized evaluation protocols ensuring cross-program comparability and rigor.
BAT.Capacity Building: Workshops on robust evaluation design, selection of qualitative and quantitative methodologies, and developing evaluation tools. (V2 MEL Slide 14)
BAT.Templates: Evaluation Toolkit, Baseline & Endline Study Framework
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Conducting Baseline, Endline, and Mid-Term Evaluations
BAT.Users/Target Audience: Internal MEL Teams, Donor Agencies, Third-Party Evaluators
BAT.Expected Outcomes: More structured evaluation cycles that measure program impact effectively.
BAT.Rationale and References: Evaluations lack standardization, leading to inconsistent findings across programs. (V2 MEL Slide 14)

BAT.Capacity Building: Training on developing fact sheets, white papers, and internal knowledge repositories to ensure organizational learning. (OH Journal Section 11.3)
BAT.Templates: Knowledge Management Repository Guide, Learning Report Templates
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Documentation, Internal Knowledge Sharing, and Learning Integration
BAT.Users/Target Audience: MEL Teams, Program Managers, Knowledge Officers
BAT.Expected Outcomes: Creation of a structured knowledge-sharing system, reducing duplication of efforts.
BAT.Rationale and References: Lack of systematic documentation results in fragmented knowledge retention. (OH Journal Section 11.3)

BAT.Deliverables: Integration of Programmatic Assumptions into MEL
BAT.Capacity Building: Workshops on identifying, documenting, and validating programmatic assumptions in outcome tracking. (OH Journal Section 7.2)
BAT.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Causal Pathway and Assumption-Based Evaluation
BAT.Users/Target Audience: Policy Teams, MEL Analysts, Strategy Consultants
BAT.Expected Outcomes: More accurate impact assessment, refined program design.
BAT.Rationale and References: Assumptions are rarely tested or documented, leading to potential gaps in outcome validation. (OH Journal Section 7.2)

SDD_BRLF.Rationale for Maturity: They have MEL System implemented at organisation level. But faces difficulty in  its implementation at the field level operations
SDD_BRLF.Current Challenges: Difficulty in allignining MEL goals with the field implemting partners due to manual data collection process or lack of capacity building of field partners.
SDD_BRLF.Experience in addressal of challenges: Transitioned from manual methods to digital tools like ODK (Open Data Kit) and are developing a proprietary app for two-way communication with their MIS (Management Information System) to reduce redundant data entry
SDD_BRLF.Support possible: Training and advisory services for MEL integration
SDD_BRLF.Key requirements: Standardized MEL framework with clear decision-making protocols
SDD_BRLF.Capacity Building: Training on MEL principles, framework integration, and standardization across projects. Hands-on workshops to implement best practices.
SDD_BRLF.Templates: MEL framework templates that align with organizational and program needs.
SDD_BRLF.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs for MEL planning, implementation, and reporting cycles.
SDD_BRLF.Users/Target Audience: Program managers, MEL staff, project teams.
SDD_BRLF.Expected Outcomes: Increased MEL consistency, data-driven decision-making, and strategic alignment.
SDD_BRLF.Rationale and References: Identified lack of standardized MEL framework across project levels

SDD_BRLF.Rationale for Maturity: They have a central level dashboard and state level dashboard. They are planning to move towards a centralised MIS System dashboard to deal with the issues of API Integration and manual reporting. But BRLF lacks unified MEL Practices across projects and programs.
SDD_BRLF.Current Challenges: BRLF maintains State Level and Central level dashboard.- Data is being generated through Excel Sheet and MIS System. From past one and half year, They have shifted to Open Data kit ODK Tool.- Challenge is that current MIS System is a one way source of data collection which created issues in verification of details. BRLF is planning to have its own app to address the issue.- Issue  with regard to the technology platforms that BRLF was using, They were using different kinds of platforms where they faced challenges with API integration because of the design of it.
SDD_BRLF.Experience in addressal of challenges: They are creating one big MIS system on a single database and a single platform so that everybody can be users there and they can reduce the number of data errors and API struggles which also needed a lot of manual interventions at different points in time.
SDD_BRLF.Support required: Development of standardized MEL practices across levels (Organisation/Project/Program)
SDD_BRLF.Support possible: MEL consulting support to develop level-wise MEL frameworks
SDD_BRLF.Key requirements: Clear demarcation of MEL practices across organizational, program, and project levels
SDD_BRLF.Capacity Building: Training on using digital dashboards, interpreting data visualizations, and making programmatic decisions based on dashboard analytics.
SDD_BRLF.Templates: Dashboard design templates with indicators and data visualization formats.
SDD_BRLF.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOPs for dashboard maintenance, data input, and validation.
SDD_BRLF.Expected Outcomes: Improved transparency, real-time performance monitoring, and enhanced decision-making.
SDD_BRLF.Rationale and References: Identified gaps in real-time data access and fragmented monitoring systems

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: FPAI’s strategic priorities include reproductive health services, sexual rights advocacy, and policy engagement, with a focus on tracking service delivery through ECMIS and DHIS2.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: FPAI has structured monitoring at the branch and HQ level, with MEL integrated into strategic planning. Decision-making is supported by monthly MEL reviews, ensuring data is utilized effectively (Transcript, 00:40:00). However, entitlement-based tracking is not consistently linked to service data, limiting advocacy MEL integration.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: The non-standardized data formats across 44 branches make MEL data aggregation difficult, leading to inconsistencies in program impact analysis. Service-level MEL tracking is structured, but advocacy MEL tracking lacks standardized indicators (Transcript, 00:35:00). Government engagement outcomes are not systematically captured, making it difficult to assess policy influence.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Monthly MEL review meetings are conducted, but lack of uniformity in reporting remains a concern. The branch-level MEL teams require training to improve integration of advocacy and entitlements into MEL reporting (Transcript, 00:40:00). FPAI has attempted advocacy data collection, but without a structured format, it remains difficult to measure long-term change.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: A structured review mechanism is needed to harmonize MEL data across branches. An improved tracking system for advocacy and policy engagement is required to link MEL data with rights-based programming. Entitlements data should be integrated into existing ECMIS and DHIS2 systems.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can provide standardized review templates, train teams on entitlement tracking, and support the development of an advocacy-focused MEL framework. MEL teams require training on process indicators to track government engagement systematically.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Strengthening data standardization across all 44 branches. Ensuring MEL captures both service delivery and advocacy impacts. Developing a clear framework to integrate advocacy MEL indicators with service-level data.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: FPAI’s MEL focuses on clinical services (SRH, contraception, abortion care), rights-based advocacy, and policy engagement but lacks a structured approach to linking programmatic and advocacy MEL indicators.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Service delivery MEL is strong due to standardized ECMIS/DHIS2 tracking, but advocacy MEL tracking lacks structured indicators (Transcript, 00:25:00). The disconnect between policy engagement efforts and MEL frameworks results in incomplete outcome measurement. Many advocacy efforts remain qualitative and lack clear data capture mechanisms.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: MEL does not fully document FPAI’s influence on policy change, making it difficult to measure effectiveness in advocacy. Data on government engagement (meetings, submissions) is scattered across reports and not systematically aggregated (Transcript, 00:35:00). The lack of a common MEL framework across advocacy and service delivery makes it difficult to track cross-programmatic learning.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: FPAI has attempted to capture policy engagement data informally, but these efforts remain inconsistent and difficult to compare across branches (Transcript, 00:35:00). Limited documentation of FPAI’s role in influencing government policies hinders advocacy MEL development. No consistent approach exists for tracking systemic shifts resulting from advocacy efforts.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Structured MEL indicators for advocacy work are required to measure policy impact and government engagement. A standardized MEL framework that aligns service delivery and policy change indicators is necessary. Capacity-building is required to train teams on tracking advocacy effectiveness.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can support advocacy MEL framework development, including structured policy engagement tracking tools. Training on qualitative and quantitative MEL approaches for advocacy would improve documentation. CMS can also design a system for tracking government meetings and submissions.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Ensuring FPAI’s MEL captures policy impact and systemic change alongside service delivery data. Developing an integrated MEL system that aligns advocacy and service MEL tracking. Improving MEL documentation for FPAI’s government and policy engagement.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: FPAI has an organization-wide Theory of Change (ToC), but it is not uniformly adapted at project levels.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: The ToC is referenced in MEL reporting but lacks structured linkages to real-time data tracking in ECMIS/DHIS2 (Transcript, 00:25:00). ToC does not clearly define how policy engagement outcomes contribute to systemic change, making it difficult to evaluate long-term impact. Some project MEL frameworks are missing standardized ToC components for outcome measurement.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: ToC does not consistently capture entitlement-based advocacy impacts, leading to gaps in assessing how FPAI’s work influences government policies (Transcript, 00:35:00). MEL teams in different branches use varying interpretations of ToC, making standardization difficult.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Policy engagement MEL tracking is underdeveloped, leading to weak links between ToC indicators and real-world advocacy impact. There is no structured ToC application across all 44 branches, limiting consistency in MEL reporting.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: ToC should be aligned with MEL at all levels to ensure service delivery, policy engagement, and entitlements MEL are integrated. Training on developing advocacy MEL indicators within ToC frameworks is required.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can provide ToC training for MEL staff, focusing on incorporating process indicators for advocacy MEL tracking. CMS can support the creation of ToC-based advocacy measurement tools.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Ensuring all MEL systems align with ToC frameworks for service and advocacy MEL tracking. Strengthening policy engagement measurement within FPAI’s ToC framework.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: Service delivery inputs (contraceptives, STI treatment, abortion services) are well-tracked, but advocacy-related inputs (policy meetings, government submissions) are not systematically recorded.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Advocacy input tracking relies on informal documentation, leading to data gaps in understanding how FPAI influences policy (Transcript, 00:20:00). MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Digital tracking of service delivery exists, but digitization of advocacy engagement is still in early stages. FPAI has attempted manual tracking of advocacy inputs, but these efforts remain unstructured and difficult to consolidate.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Development of structured advocacy input tracking tools is necessary to ensure comprehensive MEL coverage. A digital system for recording government engagement data is needed.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can provide training on digital MEL tool adoption for advocacy tracking. Support for digitizing manual advocacy input collection methods would strengthen MEL integration.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Ensuring all advocacy and government engagement inputs are systematically tracked. Integrating advocacy and service delivery MEL input tracking into a single system.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: Budget and resource allocation for quality assurance and service delivery across socio-economically diverse regions.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Partially implemented across service locations, but lacks consistent resource allocation for marginalized groups. Quality standards exist for clinical services but are inconsistently applied across different demographic groups, especially in rural areas.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Lack of standardized quality checks across socio-economic and cultural settings. Inconsistent budget disbursement affects service consistency, particularly for marginalized communities. Context-specific training is required for quality assurance staff.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Efforts to standardize quality assurance exist but remain inconsistent across branches. Some branches have piloted internal quality audits, but no comprehensive monitoring system has been adopted.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Capacity building in quality control measures and standardized budget utilization frameworks. Training on culturally responsive quality assurance.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: MEL consultants can provide training on quality assurance frameworks and budget utilization best practices, tailored to socio-economic diversity.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Ensure uniform quality assurance across service locations, with a focus on equitable access for different socio-economic and cultural groups.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: Tracking of outcomes through journals, RBMS/MIS, dashboards, and case studies, covering both service and policy outcomes.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: RBMS/MIS and dashboards exist but are not fully integrated for real-time tracking, particularly for underserved populations. Qualitative data capturing community-level changes remains weak.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Underutilization of qualitative data affects understanding of socio-cultural outcomes. Limited real-time tracking of outcomes reduces responsiveness to emerging challenges, particularly in rural and tribal areas.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Outcome journals are maintained, but data usage varies across teams. Some partners use RBMS effectively, but adoption remains inconsistent, particularly in settings with low digital literacy.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Technical assistance in improving real-time tracking systems and standardizing qualitative documentation of behavioral and cultural shifts.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: Experts in data integration can assist in refining dashboards and strengthening MIS capacities, particularly for culturally diverse populations.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Develop an integrated and real-time outcome tracking system that captures both quantitative and qualitative shifts across demographic groups.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: Baseline and endline evaluations, along with donor-specific evaluation methods, adapted for gender, caste, and economic factors.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Baseline and endline evaluations are conducted, but there is inconsistency in integrating findings into program improvements. Evaluations do not fully capture intersectional gender and economic barriers.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Limited structured evaluation feedback loops. Findings remain at the reporting stage without integration into planning. Evaluations often overlook socio-economic and cultural factors influencing service uptake.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Periodic evaluations are conducted, but there is no structured system to assess the effectiveness of implementation in culturally distinct communities. Recommendations often remain unimplemented due to lack of accountability frameworks.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Advisory support in integrating evaluation insights into strategic planning. Development of intersectional evaluation metrics capturing gender, caste, and socio-economic challenges.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: Evaluation specialists can offer guidance on embedding learning into decision-making. Training on using qualitative evaluation tools to assess barriers faced by marginalized communities.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Establish a structured and responsive evaluation system that includes feedback loops and intersectional analysis.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: Factsheets, whitepapers, newsletters, workshops, conferences, and research papers to support learning at organizational and community levels.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Learning sessions focus on service delivery, but lessons from socio-economic and cultural experiences are not well documented. Internal learning mechanisms exist, but advocacy-focused insights are not effectively shared.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Best practices from policy engagement and advocacy work are not systematically compiled. Limited integration of community knowledge into learning systems. Absence of a structured repository limits knowledge retention and application across thematic areas.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Some advocacy-related learnings have been captured informally, but there is no centralized repository to facilitate knowledge-sharing. Community perspectives on sexual and reproductive health rights (SRHR) are often missing from MEL learning systems.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Development of structured learning dissemination protocols. Creation of a centralized repository for thematic learnings across cultural and socio-economic groups.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: Knowledge management professionals can support the development of a structured learning process that integrates community-level insights.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Enhance the institutional learning framework to capture socio-cultural knowledge and improve its application in MEL systems.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: Causal pathways and implementation assumptions, particularly how socio-economic and cultural factors influence service access and health outcomes.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Programmatic assumptions around service delivery and advocacy outcomes exist, but there is no validation of how these assumptions hold across different demographic groups.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Assumptions about accessibility and service uptake in certain demographic groups have not been tested. Some interventions fail to consider socio-cultural norms, limiting effectiveness. No structured mechanism exists for assumption validation.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Previous programmatic reviews have highlighted gaps in assumption validation, particularly regarding service uptake among women in conservative communities. There is no established process to refine assumptions based on real-world data.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Strengthening validation mechanisms for assumptions. Ensuring alignment of assumptions with on-the-ground realities through continuous learning.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: Program analysts can support the refinement of assumption validation methodologies. Field-level testing of assumptions should be integrated into MEL frameworks.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Improve evidence-based program design by validating key assumptions and refining strategies based on cultural, economic, and social realities.

Implementation and Capacity Building.Deliverables: Development of a Standardized MEL Strategy
Implementation and Capacity Building.Capacity Building: Workshops on aligning MEL processes across all 44 branches and standardizing reporting to enable uniform data aggregation. (MEL Analysis, V2 MEL Slide 8)
Implementation and Capacity Building.Templates: FPAI MEL Strategy Document, MEL Framework Alignment Guide
Implementation and Capacity Building.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for MEL Data Collection, Reporting, and Decision-Making Alignment
Implementation and Capacity Building.Users/Target Audience: MEL Officers, Program Directors, Senior Leadership
Implementation and Capacity Building.Expected Outcomes: Establishing a cohesive MEL structure that ensures program-wide consistency and comparability.
Implementation and Capacity Building.Rationale and References: Identified during MEL assessment, where discrepancies in data collection formats and lack of unified indicators were observed. (MEL Analysis, V2 MEL Slide 8)

Implementation and Capacity Building.Deliverables: Training for MEL Staff on Data Validation
Implementation and Capacity Building.Capacity Building: Comprehensive training on data validation techniques, verification methods, and error-checking mechanisms to ensure accuracy and credibility in reporting. (Transcript 00:30:00, OH Journal Section 8.2)
Implementation and Capacity Building.Templates: FPAI Data Verification Checklist, Field Validation Training Manual
Implementation and Capacity Building.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Standardized Data Entry, Validation, and Error Correction
Implementation and Capacity Building.Users/Target Audience: Field MEL Teams, Data Analysts, Field Supervisors
Implementation and Capacity Building.Expected Outcomes: Reduction in reporting discrepancies, improved reliability of outcome data.
Implementation and Capacity Building.Rationale and References: Inconsistencies in data validation procedures across branches led to issues in tracking outcome-level progress. (Transcript 00:30:00, OH Journal Section 8.2)

Implementation and Capacity Building.Capacity Building: Training on adopting and using uniform templates to track outputs, outcomes, and indicators across all programs. (Transcript 00:50:00)
Implementation and Capacity Building.Templates: Outcome Harvesting Reporting Template, FPAI Quarterly Progress Report Format
Implementation and Capacity Building.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Reporting Frequency, Data Categorization, and Compliance
Implementation and Capacity Building.Users/Target Audience: Program and Project Managers, MEL Coordinators, Field Staff
Implementation and Capacity Building.Expected Outcomes: Enhanced efficiency in report generation, reduction in data inconsistencies.
Implementation and Capacity Building.Rationale and References: Partner discussions revealed challenges in synthesizing field data into a consolidated report. (Transcript 00:50:00)

Implementation and Capacity Building.Deliverables: Integration of Theory of Change into MEL Framework
Implementation and Capacity Building.Capacity Building: Capacity-building sessions on designing and aligning ToCs with program interventions to establish causal linkages. (OH Journal Section 5.1)
Implementation and Capacity Building.Templates: ToC Mapping Guide, Causal Pathways Documentation Template
Implementation and Capacity Building.Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): SOP for Developing and Applying ToCs in Program Design
Implementation and Capacity Building.Users/Target Audience: Senior Leadership, MEL Advisors, Program Teams
Implementation and Capacity Building.Expected Outcomes: Improved ability to measure long-term impact and refine program interventions.
Implementation and Capacity Building.Rationale and References: Many FPAI programs lack a structured ToC, limiting their ability to assess systemic change. (OH Journal Section 5.1)

Implementation and Capacity Building.Deliverables: Deployment of Digital Input Tracking System

Implementation and Capacity Building.Expected Outcomes: Reduction in data entry errors, increased efficiency in tracking service delivery.
Implementation and Capacity Building.Rationale and References: Manual tracking has led to reporting delays, errors, and inefficiencies. (Transcript 00:25:00)

Implementation and Capacity Building.Capacity Building: Capacity-building on establishing minimum quality benchmarks for data reporting, service tracking, and program evaluation. (V2 MEL Slide 15)

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: FPAI’s strategic priorities include reproductive health services, sexual rights advocacy, and policy engagement, with a focus on tracking service delivery through ECMIS and DHIS2.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: FPAI has structured monitoring at the branch and HQ level, with MEL integrated into strategic planning. Decision-making is supported by monthly MEL reviews, ensuring data is utilized effectively (Transcript, 00:40:00). However, entitlement-based tracking is not consistently linked to service data, limiting advocacy MEL integration.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: The non-standardized data formats across 44 branches make MEL data aggregation difficult, leading to inconsistencies in program impact analysis. Service-level MEL tracking is structured, but advocacy MEL tracking lacks standardized indicators (Transcript, 00:35:00). Government engagement outcomes are not systematically captured, making it difficult to assess policy influence.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Monthly MEL review meetings are conducted, but lack of uniformity in reporting remains a concern. The branch-level MEL teams require training to improve integration of advocacy and entitlements into MEL reporting (Transcript, 00:40:00). FPAI has attempted advocacy data collection, but without a structured format, it remains difficult to measure long-term change.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: A structured review mechanism is needed to harmonize MEL data across branches. An improved tracking system for advocacy and policy engagement is required to link MEL data with rights-based programming. Entitlements data should be integrated into existing ECMIS and DHIS2 systems.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can provide standardized review templates, train teams on entitlement tracking, and support the development of an advocacy-focused MEL framework. MEL teams require training on process indicators to track government engagement systematically.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Strengthening data standardization across all 44 branches. Ensuring MEL captures both service delivery and advocacy impacts. Developing a clear framework to integrate advocacy MEL indicators with service-level data.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Unnamed: 10: Training and advisory services for MEL integration

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: FPAI’s MEL focuses on clinical services (SRH, contraception, abortion care), rights-based advocacy, and policy engagement but lacks a structured approach to linking programmatic and advocacy MEL indicators.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: Service delivery MEL is strong due to standardized ECMIS/DHIS2 tracking, but advocacy MEL tracking lacks structured indicators (Transcript, 00:25:00). The disconnect between policy engagement efforts and MEL frameworks results in incomplete outcome measurement. Many advocacy efforts remain qualitative and lack clear data capture mechanisms.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: MEL does not fully document FPAI’s influence on policy change, making it difficult to measure effectiveness in advocacy. Data on government engagement (meetings, submissions) is scattered across reports and not systematically aggregated (Transcript, 00:35:00). The lack of a common MEL framework across advocacy and service delivery makes it difficult to track cross-programmatic learning.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: FPAI has attempted to capture policy engagement data informally, but these efforts remain inconsistent and difficult to compare across branches (Transcript, 00:35:00). Limited documentation of FPAI’s role in influencing government policies hinders advocacy MEL development. No consistent approach exists for tracking systemic shifts resulting from advocacy efforts.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Structured MEL indicators for advocacy work are required to measure policy impact and government engagement. A standardized MEL framework that aligns service delivery and policy change indicators is necessary. Capacity-building is required to train teams on tracking advocacy effectiveness.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can support advocacy MEL framework development, including structured policy engagement tracking tools. Training on qualitative and quantitative MEL approaches for advocacy would improve documentation. CMS can also design a system for tracking government meetings and submissions.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Ensuring FPAI’s MEL captures policy impact and systemic change alongside service delivery data. Developing an integrated MEL system that aligns advocacy and service MEL tracking. Improving MEL documentation for FPAI’s government and policy engagement.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Unnamed: 10: MEL consulting support to develop level-wise MEL frameworks

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: FPAI has an organization-wide Theory of Change (ToC), but it is not uniformly adapted at project levels.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: The ToC is referenced in MEL reporting but lacks structured linkages to real-time data tracking in ECMIS/DHIS2 (Transcript, 00:25:00). ToC does not clearly define how policy engagement outcomes contribute to systemic change, making it difficult to evaluate long-term impact. Some project MEL frameworks are missing standardized ToC components for outcome measurement.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: ToC does not consistently capture entitlement-based advocacy impacts, leading to gaps in assessing how FPAI’s work influences government policies (Transcript, 00:35:00). MEL teams in different branches use varying interpretations of ToC, making standardization difficult.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Policy engagement MEL tracking is underdeveloped, leading to weak links between ToC indicators and real-world advocacy impact. There is no structured ToC application across all 44 branches, limiting consistency in MEL reporting.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: ToC should be aligned with MEL at all levels to ensure service delivery, policy engagement, and entitlements MEL are integrated. Training on developing advocacy MEL indicators within ToC frameworks is required.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can provide ToC training for MEL staff, focusing on incorporating process indicators for advocacy MEL tracking. CMS can support the creation of ToC-based advocacy measurement tools.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Ensuring all MEL systems align with ToC frameworks for service and advocacy MEL tracking. Strengthening policy engagement measurement within FPAI’s ToC framework.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Unnamed: 10: Training on ToC design and implementation

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: Service delivery inputs (contraceptives, STI treatment, abortion services) are well-tracked, but advocacy-related inputs (policy meetings, government submissions) are not systematically recorded.

Government engagement and outreach tracking lack uniform input capture mechanisms, making it difficult to assess effectiveness.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: Advocacy input tracking relies on informal documentation, leading to data gaps in understanding how FPAI influences policy (Transcript, 00:20:00). There is no centralized repository for tracking government meetings and submissions, making it difficult to measure engagement levels.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Digital tracking of service delivery exists, but digitization of advocacy engagement is still in early stages. FPAI has attempted manual tracking of advocacy inputs, but these efforts remain unstructured and difficult to consolidate.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: Development of structured advocacy input tracking tools is necessary to ensure comprehensive MEL coverage. A digital system for recording government engagement data is needed.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can provide training on digital MEL tool adoption for advocacy tracking. Support for digitizing manual advocacy input collection methods would strengthen MEL integration.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Ensuring all advocacy and government engagement inputs are systematically tracked. Integrating advocacy and service delivery MEL input tracking into a single system.

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: A total of 20 farmers' groups from 5 villages are practicing Climate Adaptive Natural Farming (CANF), disaster-resilient agriculture, and diversified farming. They have also adopted improved land-use processes to enhance agricultural sustainability and resilience.
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar villages, Choto and Boro banashyamnagar and Satyadaspur villages
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: During the Kharif and Rabi seasons (August 2024 to January 2025), 20 farmer groups from Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar, Choto Banashyamnagar, Boro Banashyamnagar, and Satyadaspur villages have adopted and implemented climate-smart agricultural practices. They have transitioned to organic and mixed farming approaches on both their own lands and shared lands, demonstrating increased awareness and capacity to practice sustainable farming. This shift indicates a behavioral change towards climate resilience, reducing dependency on chemical inputs, and enhancing soil health and productivity.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: This observation is significant because it reflects a tangible shift in farmers' behaviors and agricultural practices toward climate resilience. The adoption of climate-smart, organic, and mixed farming methods demonstrates:1. Increased Awareness & Capacity – Farmers are actively applying sustainable farming techniques, showing that they understand the benefits of reducing chemical dependency and improving soil health.2. Community-Led Adaptation – The shift is not limited to individual farmers but extends across 20 farmer groups, indicating collective action and peer learning.3. Utilization of Shared Lands – The inclusion of hare (shared) lands suggests an expansion of sustainable farming beyond individual holdings, fostering resource optimization and cooperation.4. Climate Resilience & Sustainability – By adopting organic and mixed practices, farmers are better prepared to handle climate variability, ensuring long-term food security and livelihood stability.This change aligns with the program’s vision of climate-resilient and sustainable agriculture by:• Strengthening Livelihoods – Encouraging diverse, eco-friendly agricultural practices contributes to income stability and food security.• Enhancing Environmental Sustainability – Reducing chemical use improves soil fertility, biodiversity, and water conservation.• Scaling Sustainable Solutions – The adoption by multiple farmer groups demonstrates the replication potential of climate-smart practices, paving the way for wider policy or practice shifts.• Empowering Local Communities – By equipping farmers with knowledge and skills, the initiative fosters community ownership of sustainable agricultural solutions.This observation signifies progress toward the program's broader goal—enhancing farmers' resilience against climate change while promoting sustainable agro-ecological transitions
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: Team members from 360 farmers conducted capacity-building programs, Chas Chakro, Kishan Pathshala, transect walks, and exposure visits, where they trained and learned from farmer group leaders on climate-smart practices. These initiatives enhanced farmers' knowledge and skills, encouraging the adoption of organic and mixed farming methods on their own and shared lands.

Sundarbans Journal.(Social actor - individual, groups, inst: Women collectives: Pather Sathi Women's Collective,  Rubi, Sasmalpara &Sanjher Bati PAR Group members with Sarmistha womens groups
Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: All members taken ineatatives of water congestion (water logging) in the village canal;  took collective action to water remove from agriculture land by engaging with thelocal panchayat and para village committee,
Sundarbans Journal.When did it happen? (Should be after pro: Collectives afforts by 23 women members from Sripatinagar village
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Sanjher Bati PAR Group action was held at Purba Sripatinagar village in Achintyangar G.P.;                       Pather Sathi Women's Group action was held Paschim Sripatinagar village in Achintyanagar G.P.;
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: In response to water congestion (waterlogging) in the village canal, all members took collective action to remove excess water from agricultural land by engaging with the local panchayat and para village committee. A significant contribution came from 23 women members from Sripatinagar village, demonstrating strong community-led efforts in addressing the issue. Additionally, the Sanjher Bati PAR Group in Purba Sripatinagar and Pather Sathi Women's Group in Paschim Sripatinagar played key roles in mobilizing local stakeholders, ensuring effective problem-solving at the community level within Achintyanagar G.P.. These initiatives highlight an improved collective decision-making process, local governance engagement, and climate resilience practices within the community.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: This change is significant because it demonstrates community-led action and collective problem-solving in response to water congestion. Key reasons include:• Strengthened Local Governance – Engagement with the panchayat and para village committee shows increased community participation in decision-making.• Women's Leadership – The involvement of 23 women members highlights growing women's agency in local environmental management.• Disaster Resilience – Addressing water logging in agricultural land supports climate adaptation and food security by preventing crop damage.This aligns with the program’s vision of community empowerment and climate resilience by:• Promoting Collective Action – Encouraging group-led initiatives fosters long-term sustainability.• Enhancing Climate Adaptation – Water management efforts contribute to disaster preparedness and resilient farming.• Building Local Capacity – Strengthening community structures ensures sustainable solutions for environmental challenges.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: The change was driven by community awareness, collective decision-making, and proactive engagement with local governance structures. Women’s participation and farmer group mobilization played a crucial role in taking action against water congestion.• Conducted capacity-building sessions on climate resilience and water management.• Facilitated community meetings, PRA exercises, and transect walks to identify waterlogging issues.• Strengthened women’s leadership through group mobilization and decision-making platforms.• Encouraged collaboration with the panchayat and para village committee, ensuring local governance support.• Organized farmer field schools and exposure visits to learn water management best practices. These efforts empowered the community to take collective action, improve disaster resilience, and strengthen local problem-solving mechanisms.

Sundarbans Journal.(Social actor - individual, groups, inst: Housewives ( Mixed Group);           Parents of Adolescent Group members;
Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: Significant changes have been observed in family dynamics, gender equality, and women's participation in decision-making.1. Change in Behavior & Relationships: Families prioritize equal treatment for boys and girls in education, health, and clothing. Fathers and family heads now seek and respect the opinions of women in children’s education-related decisions. Women are encouraged to participate in training and community meetings at the panchayat and block levels.2. Change in Actions & Activities: Girls are allowed to attend tuition and cultural programs, which was previously restricted. Women, particularly housewives, have gained financial freedom, making small expenditures at their discretion.3. Change in Practices & Policies: Girls now use sanitary napkins instead of cloth, promoting better hygiene and health awareness. Household spending is more gender-equitable, with equal expenses on boys' and girls' clothing. These changes reflect a shift toward gender equity, women's empowerment, and improved decision-making roles for women in families and communities.
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar, Choto,  Boro banashyamnagar & Satyadaspur villages
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Ov.er the last six months, family dynamics have shifted towards gender equality, with women gaining decision-making roles and girls receiving equal opportunities in education, health, and participation. Families now prioritize equal spending on boys' and girls' needs, and women actively engage in community activities. Improved financial autonomy for housewives and enhanced menstrual hygiene practices indicate positive social transformation towards women’s empowerment and gender equity in Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar, Choto, Boro Banashyamnagar, and Satyadaspur villages
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: This change promoting equal opportunities for girls and women, enhancing their agency and promoting social transformation. The shift reflects the theory of change, in our project villages increased awareness, participation, and financial autonomy lead to sustainable gender-equitable practices and policies.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: This change has been driven by awareness programs, community training, and capacity-building initiatives that promote gender equality and women's empowerment. The program has specifically conducted workshops, facilitated discussions, and encouraged women's participation in decision-making and financial independence, leading to shifts in family dynamics and social norms.

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: Collective members are taking benefits of various welfare schemes like Krishak Bandhu, Seed Support, Swasthay Sathi, Disability Pension, Widow Pension, lakshmibhandar by engaging with officials in the concerned line department;
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar villages, Choto banashyamnagar, Banashyamnagar and Satyadaspur villages
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Collective members, including farmers, women, and adolescents, are actively accessing welfare schemes such as Krishak Bandhu, Seed Support, Swasthya Sathi, Disability Pension, Widow Pension, and Lakshmibhandar by engaging with government officials, enhancing their financial security and social protection.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: It reflects increased awareness, agency, and engagement of total 356 community members in accessing entitlements, leading to improved financial and social security. It aligns with the program vision of community empowerment by ensuring equitable access to government welfare schemes, promoting resilience, and enhancing livelihoods through informed participation.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: The change has been driven by continuous capacity-building efforts, awareness campaigns, and facilitation of direct engagement with government departments. The program has specifically contributed by:1. Knowledge Building – Conducting workshops and community meetings to educate members about available welfare schemes and eligibility criteria.2. Facilitation Support – Assisting in application processes, document preparation, and follow-ups with concerned officials.
Sundarbans Journal.Include links to any additional document: Various documents, certificates in support of the benefits obtained by members

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: Women and adolescent group members from 5 villages are actively engaged with local PRI representatives and institutional stakeholders, developing stronger relationships and collaboration. They participated in collective meetings and decision-making processes, influencing local governance and community development. This shift indicates increased agency, leadership, and recognition of their voices in local decision-making spaces.
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar villages, Choto and Boro banashyamnagar & Satyadaspur villages
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Since July 2024, representatives of local PRI and other institutions have actively participated in the meetings and observations of women and adolescent groups in Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar, Choto Banashyamnagar, and Boro Banashyamnagar villages. Their engagement has strengthened institutional linkages, facilitated better access to entitlements, and enhanced the visibility and credibility of collective actions within the community.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: It signifies increased institutional engagement with community collectives, developing stronger linkages between grassroots groups and local governance structures. It reflects progress toward inclusive decision-making, improved access to entitlements, and greater community participation in local development processes.This aligns with the program vision of empowering marginalized groups, particularly women and adolescents, by strengthening their agency and voice in governance structures. It supports the theory of change by demonstrating that active institutional participation leads to enhanced resource access, improved service delivery, and sustainable community-led development.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: This change has been contributed by continuous community mobilization, capacity-building efforts, and advocacy initiatives that strengthened the confidence and leadership skills of women and adolescent group members.Specifically, the program facilitated structured meetings between collectives and PRI representatives, conducted training on governance and rights, and encouraged active participation in decision-making processes. Regular engagement with local institutions, awareness campaigns, and strategic networking efforts have also played a key role in fostering institutional responsiveness and collaboration.

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: Over the last seven months under the ACV project, the 5 Disaster Management Taskforce (DMTF) groups have actively engaged in early warning dissemination, community risk mapping, and response planning.
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar villages, Choto and Boro banashyamnagar & Satyadaspur villages
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Since the last 7 months under the ACV project, five Disaster Management Taskforce (DMTF) groups in Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar, Choto Banashyamnagar, Boro Banashyamnagar, and Satyadaspur villages have improved disaster preparedness. They have actively engaged in early warning dissemination, community risk mapping, and response planning, enhancing community resilience to climate-induced disasters. Their proactive approach has strengthened local disaster management capacities and coordination with stakeholders.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: This change is significant because it demonstrates increased community ownership and preparedness for disaster risk reduction. The active engagement of Disaster Management Taskforce (DMTF) groups in early warning dissemination, risk mapping, and response planning enhances local resilience, reducing vulnerabilities to climate-induced disasters. The ACV project envisions empowered communities that proactively mitigate disaster risks and adapt to climate challenges. This change aligns with the theory of change by developing local leadership, strengthening preparedness mechanisms, and improving coordination between community groups and institutions, ultimately ensuring long-term disaster resilience and sustainability.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: Capacity-building sessions, hands-on training, and regular engagement with community stakeholders have strengthened the Disaster Management Taskforce (DMTF) groups' ability to respond effectively. The ACV project facilitated training on early warning systems, community risk mapping, and response planning. It also promoted collaboration between DMTF groups and local PRI institutions, ensuring better preparedness and coordination in disaster management.

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: Change of attitude and  behaviour of the adolescent  girls on menstrual taboos and boys, girls,  men and women on  social norms
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Paschim Sridharpur, Gurudaspur and Ramnagar Abad villages
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Vulnerable communities identify key issues and take individual and collective action
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: Regarding  menstrual hygiene and taboos, almost all the adolescent collective members are aware about the issues of menstrual hygiene.  Among them, in few families they are able to break  the misconceptions  with positive behaviour. In collaboration with the gram panchayat they are able to stop eve teasing in their locality.  Women and adolescents girls particularly and some of the boys are questioning on gender disparity in family etc. Thinking started with some changes of attitude and behaviour on the gender norms and practices. In some of the families, males and boys are supporting on the household chores like fetching drinking water, sending children to school, washing clothes and utensils, cooking etc. Five adolescents have stopped misuse of mobiles by peer pressure. Another two have reduced the uses of mobile phone to some extent, and trying to stop to use during study, as the peers have shared.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: Active participation in sessions, meetings, training and workshops on regular basis on the issues as per modules  following the participatory tools and technique used through which they were able to take it easily by heart.

What was the: 1.They have taken part in the panel discussion by WBCPC on " including the studies of Environment and climate change as part of the syllabus"                       2.They had participated at a conference held in Jamshedpur by DBMS where they presented the effects of Climate Change in the Sundarbans.                   3.One of the adoloscents have been awarded the Birangana Award from the WBCPC for their commendable contribution to their community.              4. Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Adolescent groups, equipped with knowledge and leadership skills, actively represent their climate-related issues at the block level and national platforms, influencing policy discussions and decision-making processes. Their lived experiences and insights drive meaningful dialogues on the intersection of climate change, child protection, and gender justice. Through collective advocacy, they contribute to shaping community-based climate adaptation strategies, ensuring that adolescent voices are recognized and integrated into broader climate resilience frameworks.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: This change is noteworthy as it shows adolescents shifting from passive recipients to active agents of change, advocating for climate issues at block and national levels. It reflects increased awareness, confidence, and leadership, aligning with the program vision of fostering adolescent agency. It validates the theory of change that equipping adolescents with knowledge, skills, and platforms enables them to influence policies, challenge harmful practices, and contribute to community resilience. Their representation strengthens advocacy efforts, ensuring grassroots realities shape systemic responses to climate change and child protection.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: This change has been driven by capacity-building initiatives, leadership training, and advocacy skill development for adolescents. The program has facilitated perspective-building sessions, peer collectivization, and engagement with stakeholders, enabling adolescents to articulate their concerns confidently. Additionally, life skills training and exposure to policy dialogues have enhanced their ability to represent climate-related issues. Consistent mentoring, access to platforms for expression, and the creation of safe spaces for discussion have also played a crucial role in empowering them to advocate at block and national levels.

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: They have taken active participation in the Gender Study Circle.
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Women participating in the Gender Study Circle are actively engaging in knowledge-sharing and dialogue on gender issues, strengthening their understanding and collective voice. Through these discussions, they are challenging gender norms, advocating for their rights, and fostering awareness within their communities. Their active participation in disseminating knowledge empowers other women and girls, creating a ripple effect that promotes gender equity and social change at both household and community levels.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: It contributes to our outcome of promoting sexual and reproductive health among women. These villages have low literacy, awareness and accessibility of health care centres due to their remote location
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: This change has been driven by regular Gender Study Circle sessions, where women engage in discussions on gender norms, rights, and social structures. The program has facilitated safe spaces for dialogue, perspective-building exercises, and knowledge-sharing activities, enabling women to articulate their experiences and insights confidently. Additionally, capacity-building workshops, peer learning, and mentorship support have strengthened their ability to lead discussions and disseminate knowledge. By fostering collective reflection and advocacy, the program has empowered women to challenge societal norms and drive change within their communities.

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: The budget for the GPDP in aspect to addressing on the issues of the child rights has been accepted and is being processed for implementation
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Outcome Statement:The budget for the VLAP, focused on addressing child rights issues, has been accepted and is now in the process of implementation. This marks a significant step toward institutional commitment and resource allocation for child protection and welfare. With the approved funding, targeted interventions can be effectively executed, ensuring better safeguards, services, and support systems for children at risk.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: This observation of change is noteworthy because it reflects a concrete commitment to child rights by securing resources for action. The acceptance and processing of the GPDP budget demonstrate institutional recognition of the issues raised, ensuring that child protection measures move from planning to implementation.This aligns with the program vision of strengthening community-led child protection mechanisms and validates the theory of change that when communities, especially local structures like the Village-Level Child Protection Committee (VLCPC), are empowered with knowledge and resources, they can advocate effectively for children's rights. The VLCPC's role in identifying key child protection concerns, influencing the VLAP, and ensuring accountability has been crucial in this process, reinforcing the importance of grassroots participation in systemic change.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: This change has been driven by advocacy efforts, capacity building, and community mobilization led by the program. The program has facilitated training sessions for the VLCPC, enabling them to identify child protection concerns and advocate for resource allocation. Additionally, stakeholder engagement meetings and technical support have strengthened the proposal and negotiation process for the VLAP budget. By equipping local committees with knowledge, tools, and a platform to voice concerns, the program has ensured that child rights issues are prioritized, leading to budget approval and steps toward implementation.

Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: GP Pradhan set up a system of supervision for the children within their jurisdiction. GP involved all local stakeholders (like local gram Sansad members, ASHA, Anganwadi Workers, Village Resource Person etc.) in this supervision system. Within this system, all aforesaid local stakeholders are engaged in the regular monitoring of the wellbeing of children of the area. This activity is incorporated as one of the agenda of FLWs during their regular home visit. As a protocol, they will immediately report to GP authority if any child risks found.
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Local and district level institutions adopt policies, procedures and practices on child safeguarding.
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: GP as a local administrator involved different stakeholders for monitoring of child safety and well-being issues. It is a major step towards system establishement / accountability in regard to GPS.
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: None

Sundarbans Journal.(Social actor - individual, groups, inst: Youth and Women 18-35 (+ 5 years) Years of Age Group, the resident of Sundarban Island catering selected vulnerable gram panchayat in South & North 24 Parganas
Sundarbans Journal.What did they do different? What was the: Total 695 Youths including femal completed their training in different trades, out of them 174 started their micro-enterprise for income generation and their income increase  is reported in the range of 5-10%.  (income change data are captured only after 6 months-9 months) of a training batch completion). There has been a positive attitude towards managing their own enterprises amongst trained youth and some livestock has also been purchased, shelters for livestock has also been constructed by few trainees as part of their micro enterprises and feed for livestock has also been produced by them. Also, the awareness and participation level of trainees in differenet programmes and trainings conducted has increased.
Sundarbans Journal.Where did it happen?(Eg. Village / block: Durbachati, Gobardhanpur, Acintanagar, Banashyamnagar in Patharpratima Block, Frezerganj in Namkhana Block, Madhusudanpur in Kakdwip Block under South 24 Parganas and Malekanghumti, Kalitala, Jogeshganj, Samsernagar, Kanaikati in Hingalganj Block under North 24 Parganas
Sundarbans Journal.Outcome Statement: Within December 2024, 695 youths got their training on different livelihood related trade, .e.g. Goat Keeping, Hen Rearing, Pond base Fish Farming, Organic Vegetable Farming out of them 174 started their micro-enterprise for income generation and their income increase  is reported in the range of 5-10%.  (income change data are captured only after 6 months-9 months) of a training batch completion).
Sundarbans Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: It contribute to the develoment of livelihood and increase in their income level and hence is significant
Sundarbans Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: Proper planning and initiavive of the project team
